subject: Cache user role in session object
commitMessage:
Cache user role in session object

We have decided to remove the async method call from the router,
such that all requests no longer invoke an extra dbus call
to get user role which improves performance a bit.

This commit re-implementing the role cache in session object.
User role fetched During authentication and persisted in session
object.Each successive request will be matched against the privilege
which is there in the in-memory session object.

This was discussed on below commit
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/39756

Tested by:

POST -D headers.txt https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions -d '{"UserName":"root", "Password": “0penBmc”}’

Followed by redfish queries

Get /redfish/v1/AccountService

Tested user role persistency

Signed-off-by: Ravi Teja <raviteja28031990@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I575599c29358e32849446ce6ee7f62c8eb3885f6

Patch Set 16:

The new flows (routing and 2 login paths) seem okay.
Per the second paragraph of the commit message, I think this makes BMCWeb sessions latch onto user account attributes (existence of the account, and the account's privilege role aka Redfish Role) at the time the session is created, and unresponsive to changes which occur afterward, until the session ends.
I'm okay doing that for performance reasons, but it does suggest some test cases:
1. Create a session for user X, then delete user X, and try to use the session.
2. Create a session for user X with privilege Role Administrator, then change user X to a lower privilege role such as ReadOnly, and try to access an admin function from that session.
same here

I think I need to call async method dbus call to getUserInfo here
But seeing issue while adding async calling in method as this method returns session

Ed
can you please what can be done here

Do we need to make the blocking call here to get the user role? I know that as per the bmcweb guideline we should not make the blocking calls.
Ed,Gunnar can throw some light here.

Ed
can you please give your input here?
What input are you looking for?  Blocking calls are disallowed for good reason.  Ideally this information would come from PAM.

I got that, see an issue having async method call to get user role as this method returns session. it may need some restructuring.


" Ideally this information would come from PAM"-> you mean we don't need read user role here?

Correct, we would read the user role from our pam conversation, that way, we're rooting our security in linux, instead of something we invented.

Eventually, it would be great if user sessions became real linux user sessions, such that dbus permissions could directly determine a users privilege level, but we're a ways off from that;  Relying on dbus for role information is not something any linux distribution I'm aware of does.
Why it isn't const?
Done
why we have removed the const &?
Done
same here.
Done

Update suggests that element already exists and you are changing it. Insert would better describe what this function does.

Emplace will return pair<existingIt, false> if there is already element in roleMap, so you are not updating existing element you are only adding new one when doesn't exist.
Done
No need to comment that, emplace works in similar way that insert so it is obvious you are adding new new element.
Done
This doesn't look like ERROR, also it would say nothing to person who reads it in logs. What is the intent of this error log?
If you keep this log, needs to be a debug.
forgot to remove adding as test trace
No need for that. Function name below already says that.
Done
nit: extract to function, that should increase readability
This is undefined behavior.
Done
Please abstract this lambda contents into its own method.
Done
Please don't use map here;  Use std::vector<std::pair<>>

is there any particular reason to avoid std::map?
can we use flat_map here?

std::map should be slower than std::vector of pairs, number of elements returned from async_method_call is quite small so sorting and fragmenting memory in this use case won't bring any benefits. vector of pairs should be faster and more memory efficient.

flat_map is sorted vector of pairs. We if compared to std::vector of pairs we only have extra sorting. Again considering number of elements in that container it may be not worth it from performance point of view (I may be wrong here), still I would say yes we won't notice the difference between flat_map and vector of pairs while we might notice the difference if std::map is used (mostly because memory allocations).

Anyway I'm not the one to decide here.
modified to use std::vector pair
Need to set an internalError here?
Done
This seems wrong that we're taking an opaque object, and parsing for a specific property, and requiring it.  If this is required, it needs to be a direct property on the resource itself, not a map.

GetUserInfo is a D-bus method call with returns  dict[string,variant[string,array[string],boolean]]

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/User/Manager.interface.yaml#L79

so need to look for "UserPrivilege" key to get privilege value

Right, that's kind of my point, it's an opaque dictionary API.  If it were a structure with a known struct (and required fields) it generally would be a regular struct, not a dict.  I'm not sure why dict was chosen here, but I'm not sure I want to rely on it in bmcweb, considering that at a type level, the fields can change without warning.

With that said, I need to do more research and make sure I actually understand the problem here.
sure Ed.
Handle your errors here please.
Done
Please don't capture req in a lambda
this is need for req.ipAddress

If you need only ipAddress do it like this:

ipAddress = req.ipAddress this way you only capture what you need.
done
Why is ldap special here?  From a user perspective, bmcweb should not be concerned about what the backend is, the user manager needs to be providing the correct data.

yes. I understand your point, but I could not find other way to do this.

user manager store user role for all local users (dbus object)
but for LDAP users  User-manager doesn't store user role for each user(user role stored for ldap group)
and as part of GetUserInfo D-bus call gets role of particular LDAP user.
this code is to update cache with particular ldap user role.
Why not delete it?
Done

bmcweb? OpenBMC? This commit? Commit <insert sha> removed ?
Typically don't see "we" (first person plural in commit msgs)
Why remove these?
